>mcphee@... wrote:
>>  The problem is that our system is quite complex, with lots of
>>  different components all feeding off the same random number stream.
>
>Maybe, that's pointing towards the real problem.

There's almost certainly some truth in this.

>Unit testing should
>strive for minimal granularity, i.e. test one component (unit) at a
>time. Depending on your current architecture and dependencies between
>components you will have to create lots of dummy and/or mock objects.
>Major refactorings might be necessary.

I agree with the granularity point, and we're certainly trying to 
follow that guideline.  The rub is two-fold.  First, as mentioned 
before, the system (a framework, actually) is some 300-400 classes at 
this point (and you could double that if you included apps built on 
top of the framework), and there are a number of layers each building 
on those that came before.  Second, all this was designed and built 
several years before our lives were blessed by JUnit, so we're now 
trying to add tests bit by bit after the fact.  Progress on this has 
been at best slow, with most of the added tests being in the lowest 
layers (where the interactions are minimized).  My worry is that if 
the only way (or the Right Way) to deal with this involves major 
refactorings (that are not otherwise seen as important - we're 
actually quite happy with most of the design), then no one's going to 
make it a priority and it isn't going to happen.

>Maybe a first step could be to give each component its own random number
>stream. Either for testing only or fpr both test and production.

This is an interesting idea, and would require further thought.  It's 
not immediately clear to me how this would affect the 
behavior/performance of the system, and it raises some design issues 
we'd have to work through.  It would, however, make these testing 
issues easier to deal with, and might actually be a Good Thing.

Thanks to all for the ideas.

	Nic
